title: Cinnamon Rolls
description: Soft, gooey cinnamon rolls with cream cheese glaze. This enriched dough teaches you about lamination (creating layers) and how sugar and fat affect fermentation.

steps.instruction: In a large bowl or stand mixer, combine flour, sugar, yeast, and salt. Add the warm milk, melted butter, and eggs. Mix until a soft dough forms, then knead on medium speed (or by hand) until smooth and elastic, about 8 minutes.
tips: This is an enriched dough — the butter, eggs, and sugar make it softer and stickier than a lean dough.
The dough should pull away from the sides of the bowl when fully kneaded.
It should feel soft, smooth, and slightly tacky, not sticky.

steps.instruction: Place the dough in a lightly oiled bowl, cover, and let it rise until doubled in size.
tips: Enriched doughs rise slower than lean doughs because fat and sugar inhibit yeast activity.
This is a key learning moment: compare this rise time to a simple lean dough.
Expect 1–1.5 hours depending on temperature.

steps.instruction: While dough rises, prepare the filling: mix the brown sugar and cinnamon together in a bowl. Have the softened butter ready.
tips: Room temperature butter spreads evenly. Cold butter will tear the dough.
You can add a pinch of salt to the filling to balance the sweetness.

steps.instruction: Punch down the risen dough and roll it out on a lightly floured surface into a rectangle about 40x30cm (16x12 inches). Spread the softened butter evenly over the surface, leaving a 1cm border at the far edge. Sprinkle the cinnamon-sugar filling evenly over the butter.
tips: Even thickness means even rolls. Take your time with the rolling pin.
The butter acts as a glue for the filling and creates layers when rolled.
The bare border at the far edge will help seal the roll.

steps.instruction: Starting from the long edge closest to you, roll the dough up tightly into a log. Pinch the seam closed. Using a sharp knife or dental floss, cut into 12 equal pieces. Place cut-side up in a greased 9x13 inch (23x33cm) baking pan, spacing evenly.
tips: Dental floss gives the cleanest cuts — slide it under the log, cross the ends, and pull to slice.
A knife works too, but use a sawing motion to avoid squishing the roll.
They should be close but not touching — they'll grow together during proofing.

steps.instruction: Cover the pan and let the rolls proof until puffy and they've expanded to fill the pan, touching each other.
tips: They should look pillowy and the dough should spring back slowly when poked.
Preheat your oven to 180°C (350°F) while they proof.
Don't rush this — under-proofed rolls will be dense in the center.

steps.instruction: Bake at 180°C (350°F) until the rolls are golden on top and cooked through.
tips: The center rolls take the longest — check that they're not doughy.
They should be golden but not dark brown (the sugar can burn).
Internal temperature should reach about 85°C (185°F).

steps.instruction: While the rolls bake, make the glaze: beat together cream cheese, powdered sugar, and vanilla until smooth. Spread the glaze over the hot rolls as soon as they come out of the oven.
tips: Glazing hot rolls lets the glaze melt slightly and seep into the crevices.
This is the payoff for all that work — don't skimp on the glaze!
